title: Quiz 4: Socialization & Personality Development
description: Understanding how individuals learn culture and develop personality through socialization agents and stages.

questions.question: Which of the following is considered the most important and primary agent of socialization during infancy?
questions.explanation: The family is the first and most fundamental agent of socialization for a child.
questions.hint: Who does a baby interact with first?

questions.question: What are the goals of socialization? (Select all that apply)

options.text: To teach social roles and skills

questions.explanation: Socialization aims to integrate individuals, teach roles/skills, and instill discipline, NOT to isolate.
questions.hint: Think about what helps a person fit into society.

questions.question: Match the type of socialization to its description:

pairs.right: Discarding old behaviors for new ones

questions.explanation: Primary = early/basic; Secondary = later/specific; Anticipatory = preparing; Re-socialization = radical change.
questions.hint: Match the timing/purpose to the term.

questions.question: Charles Horton Cooley's concept, the '___BLANK___ Self', suggests that our self-image is based on how we think others see us.
questions.explanation: The 'Looking Glass Self' involves imagining our appearance to others, imagining their judgment, and feeling pride or shame.

questions.question: According to G.H. Mead, what is the correct sequence of stages in the development of the self?
What is the term for places like prisons or mental hospitals where residents are isolated and undergo forced socialization?
questions.explanation: Total institutions regulate all aspects of a person's life under a single authority, often for re-socialization.

questions.question: In 'Repressive Socialization', the focus is on rewarding good behavior and the autonomy of the child.
questions.explanation: False. Repressive socialization focuses on obedience and punishing wrong behavior. Participatory socialization focuses on rewards and autonomy.
questions.hint: Think about the word 'Repressive' - does it sound free?

questions.question: Which phase of occupational socialization involves 'reluctantly adjusting to the more unpleasant aspects of one's job'?
questions.explanation: Conditioning involves facing the tedious reality of work. Commitment comes later with acceptance.
questions.hint: It sounds like getting used to something tough.

questions.question: Which of the following are components of the 'Looking Glass Self' theory? (Select all that apply)

options.text: How we think others see us
How we think others judge us
How we respond to that perceived judgment

questions.explanation: Cooley's theory is purely social/psychological, not biological.

questions.question: Which part of the self, according to Mead, represents the socialized aspect that considers society's expectations?
questions.explanation: The 'Me' is the social self (object). The 'I' is the response to the 'Me' (subject).
questions.hint: It's the part that knows the rules.
